banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: Protecting the brain against concussion

recommendations.blurb: Find out more about concussions in this list of recommended resources, prepared exclusively for TED by Gorgens.

recItems.blurb: This site is run by attorneys representing injured former NFL players, but the entries are balanced, comprehensive and updated regularly. A must for anyone staying current on professional and NCAA sport-related brain injury cases around the nation.
recItems.headline: NFL Concussion Litigation
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: One of the most active and well-funded sports medicine concussion programs, the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Concussion Program, is pioneering applied research. The university's high-definition fiber tracking (HDFT) offers some of the coolest insights into brain function possible now.
recItems.headline: UPMC Sports Medicine Concussion Program
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: A great piece summarizing the insidious culture of gladiator blood-sport.
recItems.headline: Richie Incognito and the NFL's Nasty Warrior Culture
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: Because levity, intelligence and snark get me every time — Dustin Fink is one of my favorite bloggers.
recItems.headline: The Concussion Blog
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: And, of course, here's how neuropsychologists can help people with concussions.
recItems.headline: Concussions: How a neuropsychologist can help
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: Charles Bernick is studying MMA fighters and found a reduction in brain volume among athletes who started before age 15.
recItems.headline: Professional fighters brain health study: Rationale and methods
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Charles Bernick, et al.
*American Journal of Epidemiology*, 2013

recItems.blurb: This article speaks to the growing concerns about the age of concussion being predictive of risk for poor outcomes and dementing disease.
recItems.headline: Relationship of collegiate football experience and concussion with hippocampal volume and cognitive outcomes
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Rashmi Singh, et al. 
*The Journal of the American Medical Association*, 2014

takeAction.blurb: **Join** your state's chapter of the Brain Injury Association and advocate for greater protection for athletes against concussions.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Kim Gorgens studies the brain's response to injury -- and advocates that we mind our (gray) matter.
nodes.whyListen:
As a neuropsychologist working for decades to understand brain injuries, Dr. Kim Gorgens has seen firsthand the damage sports-related impacts can do. And as a former chair of the State of Colorado Traumatic Brain Injury Trust Fund Board and a member of the Colorado Brain Injury Legislative Collaborative, she helped draft the Colorado law around youth sports injuries.

Gorgens is a Professor of Psychophysiology, Clinical Neuropsychology and Psychology of Criminal Behavior at the University of Denver. She manages a large portfolio of traumatic brain injury (TBI) related research and has lectured extensively on those issues (including her 2010 TED talk on youth sports concussion, a 2018 TEDxMileHigh talk on brain injuries in criminal justice, several NPR spots and an interview on CNN with Anderson Cooper). Her work has been featured in USNews, Newsweek, Salon.com  and more. She completed a postdoctoral fellowship in Clinical Neuropsychology and is board certified in Rehabilitation Psychology. She is a fellow of the American Psychological Association's Division 22, Rehabilitation Psychology and Vice President of the American Board of Rehabilitation Psychology.

Her research studies the reported injury history, cognitive function and brain biomarkers of youth and college athletes, probationers and inmates. Her mission is to better understand the short and long-term impacts of injuring our most vital organ. She has a fridge filled with human brains and a love of zombie movies (coincidence?). Simply put, she cares more about your brain than you do.

videoData.description: Neuropsychologist Kim Gorgens makes the case for better protecting our brains against the risk of concussion -- with a compelling pitch for putting helmets on kids.
videoData.socialDescription: Neuropsychologist Kim Gorgens makes the case for better protecting our brains against the risk of concussion -- with a compelling pitch for putting helmets on kids.

cues.text: So, a funny thing happened

on my way to becoming a brilliant,
world-class neuropsychologist:
I had a baby.
And that's not to say

I ever went on to become a brilliant,
world-class neuropsychologist.
Sorry, TED.
But I did go on to be a reasonably astute,
arguably world-class worrier.

One of my girlfriends
in graduate school, Marie,
said, "Kim, I figured it out.

It's not that you're more neurotic
than everyone else;

it's just that you're more honest
about how neurotic you are."
So in the spirit of full disclosure,
I brought some pictures to share.
Awwww.
(Laughter)
I'll just say: July.
(Laughter)
Zip!
(Laughter)
For safety.
(Laughter)
Water wings --
an inch of water.
And then, finally, all suited up

for the 90-minute drive
to Copper Mountain.
So you can get kind of a feel for this.

So my baby, Vander,
is eight years old now.

And, despite being cursed
with my athletic inability,
he plays soccer.
He's interested in playing football.
He wants to learn how to ride a unicycle.
So why would I worry?

Because this is what I do.
This is what I teach.
It's what I study. It's what I treat.

And I know that kids
get concussed every year.

In fact, more than four million people
sustain a concussion every year,

and these data are just
among kids under 14
who were seen in emergency rooms.
And so when kids sustain a concussion,

we talk about them getting dinged
or getting their bell rung,

but what is it that
we're really talking about?
Let's take a look.
[Concussive Force]
"Starsky and Hutch"? Arguably, yes.
So, a car accident.
Forty miles an hour into a fixed barrier:
35 Gs.

A heavyweight boxer punches
you straight in the face:
58 Gs.
(Music)
In case you missed it, we'll look again.

So look to the right-hand
side of the screen.
(Music)
What would you say?
How many Gs?
Close.
Seventy-two?
Would it be crazy to know:
The average concussive impact
is 95 Gs.

Now, when the kid
on the right doesn't get up,
we know they've had a concussion.
But how about the kid on the left,

or the athlete that leaves
the field of play?

How do we know if he or she
has sustained a concussion?
How do we know

that legislation that would require
they be pulled from play,
cleared for return to play,
applies to them?
The definition of concussion

doesn't actually require
a loss of consciousness.

It requires only a change
in consciousness,

and that can be any one
or a number of symptoms,
including feeling foggy, feeling dizzy,
hearing a ringing in your ear,

being more impulsive
or hostile than usual.

So given all of that and given
how darn neurotic I am,
how do I get any sleep at all?
Because I know our brains are resilient.

They're designed to recover
from an injury.
If -- God forbid --

any of us left here tonight
and sustained a concussion,

most of us would go on to fully recover
inside of a couple hours
to a couple of weeks.

But kids are more vulnerable
to brain injury.

In fact, high-school athletes
are three times more likely
to sustain catastrophic injuries
relative even to their college-age peers,

and it takes them longer
to return to a symptom-free baseline.
After that first injury,

their risk for second injury
is exponentially greater.

From there, their risk for a third injury,
greater still, and so on.
And here's the really alarming part:

We don't fully understand
the long-term impact of multiple injuries.

You guys may be familiar
with this research
that's coming out of the NFL.

In a nutshell,
this research suggests that,

among retired NFL players
with three or more career concussions,

the incidence of early-onset
dementing disease

is much greater than it
is for the general population.

So you've all seen that --
New York Times, you've seen it.
What you may not be familiar with

is that this research was spearheaded
by NFL wives who said,

"Isn't it weird
that my 46-year-old husband
is forever losing his keys?"

"Isn't it weird that
my 47-year-old husband
is forever losing the car?"

"Isn't it weird that
my 48-year-old husband
is forever losing his way home
in the car, from the driveway?"

I may have forgotten to mention
that my son is an only child.
So it's going to be really important

that he be able to drive
me around someday.
(Laughter)

So, how do we guarantee
the safety of our kids?

How can we 100 percent
guarantee the safety of our kids?
Let me tell you what I've come up with.
(Laughter)
If only.

My little boy's right there,
and he's like, "She's not kidding.
She's totally not kidding."
So in all seriousness:
Should my kid play football?
Should your kid play football?
I don't know.

But I do know there are
three things you can do.
The first: study up.

You have to be familiar with the issues
we're talking about today.
There are some great resources out there.
The CDC has a program, HEADS UP.
It's at CDC.gov.

HEADS UP is specific
to concussion in kids.

The second is a resource
I'm personally really proud of.

We've just rolled this out
in the last couple months --
CO Kids With Brain Injury.

This is a great resource
for student athletes,

teachers, parents, professionals,
athletic and coaching staff.

It's a great place to start
if you have questions.
The second thing is: speak up.
Just two weeks ago,
a bill introduced by Senator Kefalas

that would have required
athletes, kids under 18,

to wear a helmet
when they're riding their bike,
died in committee.
It died, in large part,
because it lacked constituent buy-in;
it lacked stakeholder traction.
Now, I'm not here to tell you

what kind of legislation
you should or shouldn't support,

but I am going to tell you
that, if it matters to you,
your legislators need to know that.
Speak up also with coaching staff.

Ask about what kind
of protective equipment is available.

What's the budget
for protective equipment?
How old it is?

Maybe offer to spearhead
a fundraiser to buy new gear.
Which brings us to: suit up.
Wear a helmet.
The only way to prevent a bad outcome

is to prevent that first injury
from happening.

Recently, one of my graduate
students, Tom, said,

"Kim, I've decided to wear a bike helmet
on the way to class."

And Tom knows that that little bit
of foam in a bike helmet
can reduce the g-force of impact by half.

Now, I thought it was because I have
this totally compelling helmet crusade,
this epiphany of Tom's.

As it turns out, it occurred
to Tom that a $20 helmet

is a good way to protect
a $100,000 graduate education.
(Laughter)
So ...
Should Vander play football?
I can't say no,

but I can guarantee that every time
he leaves the house,
that kid's wearing a helmet --
like, to the car,
or at school.
So whether athlete, scholar,
overprotected kid, neurotic mom,
or otherwise,
here's my baby, Vander,
reminding you
to mind your matter.
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation: The number of children below age 19 treated in American emergency rooms for concussions and other traumatic brain injuries increased to 250,000 in 2009 from just 150,000 in 2001.
footnotes.title: Extensive study on concussions in youth sports finds 'culture of resistance' for self-reporting injury; not enough evidence to support claim that helmets reduce concussion risk

footnotes.author: Steven P. Broglio et al.
footnotes.annotation:
High school football athletes sustain greater accelerations after impact than their older counterparts. Find out more in this article on the laws of motion and the mechanics of injury:

Jeffrey Barth, "[Acceleration-deceleration sport-related concussion: The gravity of it all](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC155415/)," *Journal of Athletic Training*, July-September 2001
footnotes.title: Head impacts during high school football: A biomechanical assessment

footnotes.author: Paul McCrory et al.
footnotes.title: Consensus statement on concussion in sport: The 4th International Conference on Concussion in Sport

footnotes.author: Semyon Slobounov et al.
footnotes.title: Differential rate of recovery in athletes after first and second concussion episodes

footnotes.annotation:
Some articles on longer recovery times for younger athletes:

Rosemarie Scolaro Moser et al., "[Prolonged effects of concussion in high school athletes](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16094159)," *Neurosurgery*, August 2005

Anita Sim et al.,"[Prolonged recovery of memory functioning after mild traumatic brain injury in adolescent athletes](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18312098)," *Journal of Neurosurgery*, March 2008

Tracey Covassin et al., "[The role of age and sex in symptoms, neurocognitive performance, and postural stability in athletes after concussion](http://ajs.sagepub.com/content/early/2012/04/26/0363546512444554)," *American Journal of Sports Medicine*, April 26, 2012

Some articles on the increased risk for future injuries:
Mark R. Schulz et al., "[Incidence and risk factors for concussion in high school athletes](http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/content/160/10/937.short)," *American Journal of Epidemiology*, 2004

Alexis Chiang Colvin et al., "[The role of concussion history and gender in recovery from soccer-related concussion](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19460813)," *American Journal of Sports Medicine*, September 2009

Kevin M. Guskiewicz et al., "[Cumulative effects associated with recurrent concussion in collegiate football players](http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=197667)," *Journal of the American Medical Association*, November 19, 2003

Kevin M. Guskiewicz et al., "[Epidemiology of concussion in collegiate and high school football players](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11032218)," *American Journal of Sports Medicine*, September/October 2000

There is an avalanche of research on the long-term outcomes related to dozens of concussions and thousands of sub-concussive blows. Several neurodegenerative diseases have been identified to be over-represented in athletes (some as young as 18) including [Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy](http://www.bu.edu/cte/files/2012/08/Baugh_Chronic-Traumatic-Encephalopathy_2012.pdf) (CTE).

Here's a 2014 [summary of CTE](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24907288) and other issues for parents.

The CDC has the [best informational site](http://www.cdc.gov/concussion/headsup/index.html) for official content (though data lags by a few years).

Watch a [video on concussion for high school coaches](http://www.cdc.gov/traumaticbraininjury/ctk_video_wm_bb.html). This meets all state criteria for coaching education on concussion.

Check out the REAP Project [concussion management guidelines](http://issuu.com/healthone/docs/reap_oct21/1?e=1811185/5400960).

Colorado's [innovative online tool](http://cokidswithbraininjury.com/) for educators, school administrators, school psychologists, professionals in related services, and families. The educator matrices, identification protocols and information on Response to Intervention (RTI) are invaluable.

There is, of course, no such thing as a concussion-proof helmet. Helmets will never *prevent* all concussive injuries but instead have the potential to reduce the severity of injury.

Virginia Tech-Wake Forest University's School of Biomedical Engineering and Sciences has one of the more robust helmet testing facilities, and [their data](http://www.sbes.vt.edu/helmet.php) is posted online.

Helmets reduce g-force of impacts by 50 percent. See research from the [Purdue University Neurotrauma Group](http://www.purdue.edu/research/png/research.php)  and the [UCLA Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science](http://newsroom.ucla.edu/stories/developing-new-materials-to-prevent-248008), and a terrific entry from the California State Science Fair from [Davis Boring](http://www.usc.edu/CSSF/Current/Projects/J1302.pdf).

Also these articles: ["Do football helmets reduce acceleration of impact in blunt head injuries?"](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1553-2712.2001.tb00171.x/abstract) and ["Can helmet design reduce the risk of concussion in football? Technical note."](http://thejns.org/doi/abs/10.3171/2014.1.JNS13916)

And finally, here's a point-counterpoint on whether bike helmets are useful: [no](http://www.helmets.org/walkerstudy.htm) vs. [yes](http://bigthink.com/neurobonkers/the-bike-helmet-paradox)

Note that the "no" study found that *motorists* passed closer if the bicyclist was wearing a helmet.
